string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="This video will introduce important considerations for building an accessible online classroom." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="As online learning becomes more common and online learning tools more ubiquitous in education, user-friendly and accessible online experiences will be an important consideration for educators as they design activities and assignments." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Accessibility refers to the design and development of online learning environments in a way that ensures everyone can access and participate fully. Creating an accessible online course means that students with disabilities or learning differences have the same access to the learning material as students without disabilities. If a course is designed without being mindful of student variability, the course can end up creating barriers that exclude students from accessing the material in the same way. Following UDL guidelines for accessibility can optimize your teaching and create positive learning experiences for all students. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) mandates comparable educational opportunities for individuals with disabilities, and online accessibility is included within this act. The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) provides guidelines to ensure web content, applications, browsers, and authoring tools are accessible. These guidelines ensure that tools used to create web content (like PowerPoint or course development software) are themselves accessible to both users and developers with disabilities, facilitating the creation of more accessible online materials. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="In addition to these legal considerations, there are also ethical implications for accessibility in online course design. The ADA focuses on the bare minimum necessary to curb discrimination against people with disabilities, while UDL strives to meet best practices for every student’s diverse needs." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Inaccessible materials create barriers and exclude learners with disabilities from full participation and hinders their academic access. This can lead to frustration and diminished self esteem for these individuals. Conversely accessible design benefits all learners by creating more user-friendly materials and creates a more inclusive environment. Prioritizing accessibility is not just about compliance, it's about creating equitable learning experiences that empower all students. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Now, let’s look at some specific considerations for an accessible online classroom. In an online classroom, it is of utmost importance to use and create accessible digital content. This includes: 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Displaying information in a flexible format so that features like size of text or visuals, contrast, volume, rate of speech, or speed of videos/ animations can be adjusted by the student. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Including captioning on videos and providing transcripts for any videos or audio recordings. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Providing alt-text for all visuals, graphs, and images used in your materials. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="It is also important to recognize that there are many types of visual impairments. Some students may use a screen reader, while others may not need a screen reader but may need to adjust how they view materials. To help these students,
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Ensure that text is clear, avoid using all caps, and use sans-serif fonts to ensure readability. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Make sure that background colors stand out and that the color contrast is high.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Give students choices on how to present materials when appropriate.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="Use clear, concise language in your lessons." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style StyleKey="white" /> <Span Text="It is helpful to be informed about assistive technologies that your students may be using in your classroom. It will help you to determine if your content can be used with different assistive tech, like screen readers. A resource to explore some of these assistive technologies is included in this module. You can use accessibility checkers, like WebAIM, to see if your materials are accessible for all students. Some tools, like Google Docs, even have built-in accessibility checkers that you can utilize as you are developing your lessons." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
